questions.content: A closed vessel contains a mixture of two diatomic gases <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>B</mi></math>. Molar mass of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi></math> is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>16</mn></math> times that of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>B</mi></math> and mass of gas <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi></math> contained in the vessel is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>2</mn></math> times that of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>B</mi></math>. Which of the following statements is false?
questions.subject: Physics

options.content: Average kinetic energy per molecule of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi></math> is equal to that of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>B</mi></math>.

Root mean square value of translational velocity of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>B</mi></math> is four times that of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi></math>.
Pressure exerted by <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>B</mi></math> is six times of that exerted by <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi></math>.
Number of molecules of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>B</mi></math> in the cylinder is eight times that of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi></math>.

questions.explanation:
RMS velocities of gases A and B at temperature T are,

vrmsA=3RTMA, 

vrmsB=3RTMB

⇒vrmsAvrmsB=MBMA=MB16MB=14

Number of moles of A=mAMA

Number of moles of B=mBMB

=mA2MA16=8nA

From,

PV=nRT

Pressure exerted by a gas in a given vessel at a given temperature depends on the number of molecules present inside.

questions.content: One of the lines in the emission spectrum of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>L</mi><msup><mi>i</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></math> has the same wavelength as that of the <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msup><mn>2</mn><mtext>nd </mtext></msup></math> line of Balmer series in hydrogen spectrum. The electronic transition corresponding to this line is:
questions.subject: Physics
questions.explanation:
According to Rydberg's expression for the emission spectrum, wavelength is stated as 1λ=Z2R1n12-1n22, here n1 and n2 is the principal quantum number of the initial and final state, Z is the atomic number and R is Rydberg's constant.

For 2nd  line of Balmer series in the hydrogen spectrum, Z=1
1λ=R(1)122-142=316R
For Li2+, Z=3 

Thus, we will multiply the principal quantum numbers by the atomic number of Li2+.

1λ=R(3)2162-1122=316R

which is satisfied by only (D).

questions.content: What will be current through the 200 Ω resistor in the given circuit, a long time after the switch K is switched on?
questions.subject: Physics
questions.explanation:
In steady state, arm having capacitors does not allow flow of current. So, we can neglect them.
∴ The given circuit reduces to

∴  Rnet=200+400=600Ω

∴ Current in circuit,

I=VR=6600=0.01 A

=10 mA

questions.content: When a string fixed at its both ends vibrates in <math><mn>1</mn><mi> </mi></math>loop, <math><mn>2</mn><mi> </mi></math>loops, <math><mn>3</mn></math> loops and <math><mn>4</mn></math> loops, the frequencies are in the ratio
questions.subject: Physics
questions.explanation:
When the string vibrates in loops n , its frequency is υn=nv2L
Where L  is the length of the string and v  is the velocity of the wave.
∴   When the string at its both end vibrates in 1  loop, 2 loops, 3  loops, 4  loops, The frequencies are in the ratio 1 :2 :3 :4 .

questions.content: A sphere of radius <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>R</mi></math> and density <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> is dropped in a liquid of density <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>σ</mi></math>. Its terminal velocity is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>. If another sphere of radius <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>R</mi></math> and density <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> is dropped in the same liquid, its terminal velocity will be
questions.subject: Physics
questions.explanation:
Viscous force acting on a spherical ball is given by 6πηrv, where η is the viscosity of the medium, r is the radius of the sphere and v is the velocity of the sphere.

when sphere reaches terminal velocity, net force will be zero.

6πηRv1=43πR3ρ1-σ

6πηRv2=43πR3ρ2-σ

∴v2v1=ρ2-σρ1-σ⇒v2=ρ2-σρ1-σv1.

questions.content: A body is projected with the velocity u1 from the point A as shown in figure. At the same time another body is projected vertically upwards with the velocity u2 from the point B. What should be the value of u1u2 for both the bodies to collide.
questions.subject: Physics
questions.explanation:
The two bodies will collide, if they reach at a point acquiring the same vertical distance in the same time.
             
          y=u1sin 60∘×t-12gt2=u2t-12gt2

⇒u1×32×t=u2t

⇒u1u2=23

questions.content: A ball is released from rest from point P of a smooth semi-spherical vessel as shown in figure. The ratio of the centripetal force and normal reaction on the ball at point Q is A while angular position of point Q is α with respect to point P. Which of the following graphs represent the correct relation between A and α when ball goes from Q to R?
questions.subject: Physics
questions.explanation:
At angular position α as shown in the figure, applying conservation of mechanical energy

mgRsinα=12mv2⇒mv2R=2mgsinα

In the radial direction,

N-mgsinα=mv2R⇒N=3mgsinα

Now the ratio of centripetal force and normal reaction is,

A=mv2RN=2mgsinα3mgsinα=23.  Therefore, A is constant.

questions.content: An expression of energy density is given by <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>u</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mi>α</mi><mi>β</mi></mfrac><mi>sin</mi><mfenced><mfrac><mrow><mi>α</mi><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>k</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac></mfenced></math>, where <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>α</mi><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mi>β</mi></math> are constants, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math> is displacement, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>k</mi></math> is Boltzmann constant and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>t</mi></math> is the temperature. The dimensions of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>β</mi></math> will be
questions.subject: Physics
questions.explanation:
Given that energy density u=αβsinαxkt

As αxkt should be dimensionless, the dimensions of αx and kt should be same.

⇒αx=kt⇒α=ktx

Now,

u=αβ

⇒β=αU=ktxEV=EttxEV

⇒β=L3L=M0L2T0

questions.content: What will be the mercury scale reading at <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>40</mn><mo> </mo><mo>°</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> if in mercury thermometer the ice point is marked as <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>10</mn><mo>°</mo></math> and the steam point is marked as <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>130</mn><mo>°</mo></math>.
questions.subject: Physics
questions.explanation:
Use the formula given below,

steam point-ice pointgiven temp-ice point=constant

here the steam point is 100°C, ice point is 0°C and given temperature is 40°C.

100-040-0=constant  ...1,

now if the ice point is replaced by 10°C and the steam point is replaced by 130°C then,

130-10x-10=constant  ...2

now from equation 1 & 2

100-040-0=130-10x-10⇒100x-1000=5200-400⇒x=58°

questions.content: Two particles A and B of masses mA and mB respectively, having the same charge are moving in a plane. A uniform magnetic field exists perpendicular to this plane. The speeds of the particles are vA and vB respectively and the trajectories are as shown in the figure. Then
questions.subject: Physics
questions.chapter: Magnetic Effects of Current and Magnetism
questions.explanation:
When a charged particle is moving at a right angle to the magnetic field, then a force acts on it which behaves as a centripetal force and moves the particle in a circular path.

But, r=pqB    where,  p=mv
â€‹ 

Radius of B is less than radius of A.
rB < rA

∴pB<pA

mBvB<mAvA

⇒mAvA>mBvB.

questions.content: The circuit has two oppositely connected ideal diodes in parallel. What is the current flowing in the circuit?
questions.subject: Physics
questions.explanation:
In the given circuit, diode D1 is reverse biased while D2 is forward biased.

[∵ For ideal diodes, reverse biased means open and forward biased means short.]

Apply Kirchhoff's second law to get current flowing through the circuit.

The sum of total potential in closed loop is equals to zero,

-12+4i+2i=0

⇒ i=126=2 A.

questions.content: A body of mass <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>m</mi></math> is taken from the Earth's surface to the height equal to twice the radius <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>(</mo><mi>R</mi><mo>)</mo></math> of the earth. The change in potential energy of the body will be,
questions.subject: Physics
questions.explanation:
The general formula of gravitational potential energy is, U=–GMmr where, r is the distance from the center of the earth, M is mass of earth and m is mass of object.

 

Ui=– GMmR   ...(potential energy at R)

Uf=– GMm3R   ...(potential energy at 3R)

∆U=Uf-Ui=– GMm3R--GMmR

=GMmR1–13=23GMm×RR×R=23mgR  (where, g=GMR2).

questions.content: Three blocks A, B and C are pulled on a horizontal smooth surface by a force of 80 N as shown in figure. The tensions T1 and T2 in the string are respectively:
questions.subject: Physics
questions.explanation:
Since, the length of the string will remain same. Hence, all blocks will have the same acceleration.

aA=aB=aC=F5+3+2=8010=8 m s-2

Therefore, T1=5×8=40 N.

Now,

T2-T1=3×8⇒T2=64 N

questions.content: A mass m is attached to two springs as shown in figure. The spring constants of two springs are K1 and K2. For the frictionless surface, the time period of oscillation of mass m is
questions.subject: Physics
questions.explanation:
For the given combination, if the block is displaced towards right, elongation in one spring will be equal to the compression in other and the direction of force due to both spring will be the same and restoring in nature. Hence, both springs are effectively in parallel combination.

Therefore,

⇒Keff=K1+K2 and

⇒T=2πmKeff=2πmK1+K2

questions.content: When the angle of incidence on a material is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>60</mn><mo>°</mo></math>, the reflected light is completely polarized. The velocity of the refracted ray inside the material is (in <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mo> </mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></math>)
questions.subject: Physics
questions.explanation:
As we know, μ=tan i=tan 60°
⇒μ=3
Therefore,

v=cμ=3×1083=3×108 m s-1

questions.content: An electromagnetic wave going through vacuum is described by <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>E</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mi>sin</mi><mfenced><mrow><mi>k</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mo>𝜔</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfenced></math>. Which of the following is independent of the wavelength?
questions.subject: Physics
questions.explanation:
The equation of an electromagnetic wave propagating in the positive x-axis is given by,

E=E0sin kx-ωt,

where k is known as propagation constant and is given by,

k=2πλ

and ω is the angular frequency and is given by,

ω=2πcλ

Hence, 

k2π=ω2πc⇒kω=1c

Therefore, no wavelength is associated with any term in the above equation.

questions.content: In a series LR circuit, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>X</mi><mi>L</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>R</mi></math>. Now, a capacitor <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>X</mi><mi>C</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mi>R</mi></math> is added in series. The ratio of new to old power factor is
questions.subject: Physics
questions.explanation:
Given,

XL=3R and Xc=R

When only an inductor and resistor are present in the circuit,

The impedance is, 

Z1=R2+XL2

The power factor in this case is,

(PF)1=RZ1=RR2+9R2=110

When capacitor is also added to the circuit the impedance becomes,

Z2=R2+(XL-Xc)2

the new power factor is given by,

(PF)2=RZ2

=RR2+3R-R2=RR2+4R2=15

⇒PF2(PF)1=15110=2

questions.content:
A fixed mass of gas is taken through a process A→B→C→A. Here A→B is isobaric, B→C is adiabatic and C→A is isothermal.

The pressure at C is given by (γ=1.5)
questions.subject: Physics
questions.explanation:
For isobaric process AB(pressure constant): pA=pB    ...Eqi

For adiabatic process BC: pBVBγ=pCVCγ      ...Eqii
For isothermal process CA, pAVA=pCVC       ...Eqiii
From Equation i, (ii) and (iii), we get

pBVBγpAVA=pCVCγpCVC

⇒VC=VBγVA1γ-1=4γ11γ-1
For γ=1.5, VC=43=64 m3
∴pC=pAVAVC=10564 N/m2

questions.content: Find the x coordinate of the centre of mass of the non-uniform rod of length L given below. The origin is taken at the left end of the rod. The density of the rod as a function of its x-coordinate is ρ=ax2+bx+c, where a, b and c are constants.
questions.subject: Physics
questions.explanation:
xCM=∫0Lρdx×x∫0Lρdx

=∫0L(ax3+bx2+cx)dx∫0L(ax2+bx+c)dx


=ax44+bx33+cx220Lax33+bx22+cx0L

=3aL4+4bL3+6cL2122aL3+3bL2+6cL6

=3aL3+4bL2+6cL22aL2+3bL+6c

questions.content: Two point charges <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfenced><mrow><mo>+</mo><mi>Q</mi></mrow></mfenced></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfenced><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>Q</mi></mrow></mfenced></math> are fixed on the <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>X</mi></math> -axis at positions <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>a</mi></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>2</mn><mi>a</mi></math> from origin, respectively. At what positions on the axis, the resultant electric field is zero?
questions.subject: Physics
questions.explanation:
Suppose the electric field is zero at a point P lies at a distance d from the charge +Q

The electric field is given by,

E=kQr2

At point P,

kQd2=k2Q(a+d)2

⇒d=a(2-1)

Since d>a, the point P must lies on negative x-axis.

⇒x=d-a⇒x=a(2-1)-a⇒x=-2a

questions.content: An <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi><mi>C</mi></math> circuit drawing power from a source of angular frequency <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>50</mn><mo> </mo><msup><mi>rads</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></math> has a power factor of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>0</mn><mo>.</mo><mn>6</mn><mo> </mo><mo>.</mo></math> In this condition, a resistance of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>100</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></math> is present and the current is lagging behind the voltage. If a capacitor is connected in series, then the required capacitance (in <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>μ</mi><mi>F</mi></math> )that will result in a power factor of unity is :
questions.subject: Physics
questions.explanation:
As the current lags the voltage, the circuit must contain a combination of resistance and inductance. Power factor cosϕ=0.6

⇒RR2+XL2=0.6⇒R2+XL=2R0.62⇒XL2=R2(0.6)2-R2⇒XL2=R2×0.64(0.6)2⇒4 R3=XL

Now we want the power factor cosϕ=1. This is the condition of resonance in which XL=XC.

∴  XC=4 R3⇒  1ωC=4 R3
⇒ C=34×50×100=150 μF

questions.content: A particle of mass <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>250</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></math> executes a simple harmonic motion under a periodic force <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>F</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>(</mo><mo>–</mo><mn>25</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi></math>. The particle attains a maximum speed of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>4</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mo> </mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></math> during its oscillation. The amplitude of the motion is ______<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>cm</mi></math>.
questions.subject: Physics
questions.explanation:
Given, force F=(–25x) N

⇒0.25a=-25x

⇒a=-100x

Now comparing it with standard equation, a=-ω2x we get

ω=10.

Now, vmax=ωA

⇒ωA=4

⇒A=410=0.4 m

⇒A=40 cm.

questions.content: The equivalent capacitance between points A and B in below shown figure will be _____ μF.
questions.subject: Physics
questions.explanation:
Point 3 and 4 are at same potential, hence we can replace the capacitor with a wire.


Capacitors between points A and 3 are in parallel combination as shown above and their combined capacitance value will be 3C.

This 3C capacitance is in series with C.
The equivalent capacitance of the system between points A and B is, 
CAB=3C×C3C+C=3C4
⇒CAB=34×8 μF=6 μF

questions.content: When a charged particle is accelerated through 1.5 volts its de-Broglie wavelength is λ1 and it is λ2 when the same particle is accelerated through 13.5 volts. The ratio λ1λ2(to the nearest integer) is_______.
questions.subject: Physics
questions.explanation:
de-Broglie wavelength for a charged particle,

λ=h2mqV

∴λ∝1V

∴  λ1λ2=V2V1

∴  λ1λ2=13.51.5=3

questions.content: What is the possible error <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>(</mo><mtext>in</mtext><mo> </mo><mo>%</mo><mo>)</mo></math>  in surface tension? If the following observations were taken for determining surface tension <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>T</mi></math> of water by capillary method: Diameter of capillary <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo> </mo><mo>(</mo><mi>D</mi><mo>)</mo><mo> </mo><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>.</mo><mn>50</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mo>,</mo></math> Rise of water <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>(</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">h</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>.</mo><mn>00</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></math> Using <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>.</mo><mn>80</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mo>/</mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math> and the simplified relation <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mi>rhg</mi><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mn>3</mn></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mo>/</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mo>,</mo></math>
questions.subject: Physics
questions.explanation:
D=1.50×10-2m;h=3.00×10-2m

The maximum permissible error in D=ΔD=0.01×10-2m

The maximum permissible error in h =Δh=0.01×10-2m
T=rhg2×103N/m=dhg4×103N/m

Relative error ΔTT=Δdd+Δhh+Δgg

Since g is given as a constant, we can write

∴  Percentage error,

ΔTT×100=Δdd×100+Δhh×100

=0.01×10-21.50×10-2+0.01×10-23.00×10-2×100%

=1%

questions.content: Displacement of a particle undergoing circular motion is given as <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>θ</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><msup><mi>t</mi><mn>3</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>t</mi></math>, where <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>θ</mi></math> is in radians and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>t</mi></math> in seconds. Find the angular velocity(in <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>rad</mi><mo> </mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></math>) of the particle at <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></math>.
questions.subject: Physics
questions.explanation:
The angular displacement is given as θ=2t3+t

The angular velocity can be found out by differentiating with respect to time

ω=dθdt=6t2+1   ...i

For t=4 s,

 ω=616+1⇒ω=97 rad s-1

questions.content: The figure shows infinitely long bent wires in the plane of paper, each carrying a current i with O as origin and x and y axes as shown. The co-ordinates of points P and Q are (2 m, 0) and (6 m, 0), respectively. The magnetic induction at P is given by αμ0i32π. What is the value of α?
questions.subject: Physics
questions.chapter: Magnetic Effects of Current and Magnetism
questions.explanation:
First, recall the formula of the magnetic field due to finite-length straight wire,

B=μ0i4πrsinϕ1+sinϕ2.

The magnetic field at P is only due to portions AO and BQ and direction of the field at P due to both sections will be the same.

BP=μ0i4π×2+μ0i4π×4=3μ0i16π

Then, the value of α,

αμ0i32π=3μ0i16π⇒α=6

questions.content: Consider a string which is suspended from the ceiling. The length of the string is 98 mm when a load of 60 N is suspended from a string and the length of the string is 102 mm when a load of 100 N is suspended from a string. If the area of cross-section is unchanged in the entire process, the length (in cm) of the string when a load of 150 N is suspended is α. Write the value of 10α.
questions.subject: Physics
questions.explanation:
Extension, l=mgLAY

For same wire stretched under different loads,l1l2=m1gm2g

Given: L+l1=98mm=9.8cm

L+l2=102mm=10.2cm

∴  l1l2=9.8-L10.2-L

∴  9.8-L10.2-L=60100=35

∴  49-5L=30.6-3L

∴  2L=18.4⇒L=9.2cm

Let length of wire be l3 when load of 150 N is suspended from it.

∴extension l3=L3-L

Now, l3l1=L3-L9.8-L=L3-9.29.8-9.2=L3-9.20.6

But l3l1=m3gm1g=15060

∴  L3-9.20.6=15060

∴  L3-9.2=150×0.660=1.5

∴  L3=1.5+9.2=10.7 cm=α⇒10α=107

questions.content:
Predict the product C obtained in the following reaction of 1 - butyne.
CH 3 CH 2 - C ≡ CH + HCl ⟶ B ⟶ HI C
questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.explanation:
Electrophilic Addition Reaction.
According to Markownikoff's rule, during hydro - halogenation to unsymmetrical alkene, the negative part of the addendum adds to less hydrogenated (i.e., more substituted) carbon atom.

When a protic acid (HX) is added to an asymmetric alkene, the acidic hydrogen attaches itself to the carbon having a greater number of hydrogen substituents whereas the halide group attaches itself to the carbon atom which has a greater number of alkyl substituents.

The given reactant is alkyne. When two HX molecules are treated with alkyne, both the halogen atoms are attached to the same carbon, according to Markownikoff's rule.

Here, the product formed is 2-chloro-2-iodo butane. So, option C is the correct answer.

questions.content: The <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>CFSE</mi></math> value of an octahedral complex is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>-</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>.</mo><mn>6</mn><mo> </mo><msub><mo>∆</mo><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>.</mo></math> If the metal ion is surrounded by weak ligands, what will be the magnetic moment? (spin only)

questions.explanation:
Given, CFSE value of the octahedral complex =-0.6 ∆0.

From CFSE formula,

CFSE =-0.4∆0(nt2g) +0.6∆0(neg)+xP

nt2g=  total number of electrons in triply degenerated orbital.

neg = total number of electrons in doubly degenerated orbital

x=  number of pairing takes place during complex formation

P=  pairing energy.

If CFSE has to be -0.6 ∆0, it is possible for a weak field ligand with d4 configuration which has the configuration of t2g3 eg1.

The number of unpaired electrons (n)=4

Magnetic moment =n(n+2)BM

=24 BM ~ 4.9 BM.

questions.content:
For the above sequence of reactions, identify the correct statements.
(a) A has more pKa than D.
(b) B can be prepared by the deamination of m-toluidine.
(c) A and D show HVZ reaction.
(d) A can be prepared from D by reduction with H2, CuCr2O4.
questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.explanation:
In the first step, the formation of Grignard reagent takes place which undergoes a nucleophilic addition at CO2 and hence, benzoic acid is formed.

In the second step, the benzoic acid is reduced by P and HI and toluene is obtained as the product.

The third step is an aromatic electrophilic substitution reaction and bromination takes place at the ortho- and the para- position. 

The fourth step is the oxidation process of alkylbenzene and a carboxylic acid is obtained.

D is more acidic than A because of the ortho- effect. Hence, its pKa is less than A.

Both A and D are carboxylic acids but do not contain alpha-H atom, so, HVZ reaction is not possible.

The deamination of m-toluidine forms toluene as the product.

According to Arrhenius K=Ae-EaRT

The rate constant of a reaction is equal to rate of reaction at unit concentration, which says about number of molecules converted into product .

options.content: Equation can be used to calculate the change in energy when the electron changes orbit.

For <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></math>, the electron has a more negative energy than it does for <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math> which means that the electron is more loosely bound in the smallest allowed orbit.
The negative sign in equation simply means that the energy of electron bound to the nucleus is lower than it would be if the electrons were at the infinite distance from the nucleus.
Larger the value of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi></math>, the larger is the orbit radius.

questions.explanation:
Given, equation is  E=- 2.178 × 10-18 J z2n2

For n=1, the electron has more negative energy than it does for n=6 which means that the electron is strongly bonded in the smallest allowed orbit.  The energy of an electron becomes more negative as it gets closer to the nucleus because of the increasing attractive force, with lower orbit levels (n) having more negative energy.

For n=1E=-2.178×10-18×z212=-2.178×10-18×z2J

For n=6E=-2.178×10-18×z262=-6.05×10-20 ×z2J

Hence, option B is the answer.

questions.explanation:
The melting point of a metal is affected primarily by the extent of metallic bonding (interatomic interaction in metals). The high melting points of the metals are due to the greater number of electrons from (n-1) d  electrons in addition to ns electrons in the metallic bonding.

Usually, greater is the number of unpaired electrons, greater is the extent of metallic bonding. One unpaired electron per d-orbital gives rise to maximum possible metallic bonding. The values of Mn andTc in 3d and 4d series are anomalous. The element II is Mn and I is Tc.

questions.content: The hyperconjugation stabilities of tert-butyl cation and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>2</mn></math>-butene, respectively, are due to.
questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.chapter: Some Basic Principles of Organic Chemistry
questions.explanation:
Hyperconjugation is due to the interaction of the electrons in σbond (C-H or C-C) with adjacent empty or partly filled non-bonding p-orbital,  antibonding π orbital, or filled π orbital. This results in extended molecular orbital and increases the stability of the system.
In tert-butyl cation, the carbon-bearing positive charge has an empty p-orbital and hence hyper-conjugation here involves σ—p (empty) electron delocalization.

Whereas in the case of 2-butene, there are 2 electrons in the π bond, one electron from each of the two carbon atoms i.e., π-MO contains a pair of electrons but π*MO is empty. Therefore, electrons of the σ C-H bond can move only into the π* orbital.

questions.content: Which of these represents the correct order of their increasing bond order.
questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.explanation:
According to MOT,
The electronic configuration of O2 is σ1s2, σ1s*2, σ2s2, σ2s*2, σ2px2, π2py2, π2pz2, π2py*1, π2pz*1

The electronic configuration of O22- is σ1s2, σ1s*2, σ2s2, σ2s*2, σ2px2, π2py2, π2pz2, π2py*2, π2pz*2

The electronic configuration of C2+ is σ1s2, σ1s*2, σ2s2, σ2s*2, π2py2, π2pz1

The electronic configuration of C22- is σ1s2, σ1s*2, σ2s2, σ2s*2, π2py2, π2pz2, σ2px2

The bond order=12(Nb – Na)
Where, Nb are the number of bonding electrons and Na are the number of anti-bonding electrons.

Therefore, the bond order of O22-=12(10– 8)=1
Bond order of C2+ is=12(7–4)=1.5

Bond order of O2=12(10–6)=2

Bond order of C22-=12(8–2)=3

Therefore, the correct order of their increasing bond order is O22- < C2+< O2  < C22-.

questions.content:
How many pairs are there, in which 2nd species has lower ionization energy than the first species?

(a) Be and B (b) P and S (c) O and S (d) Br and K (e) N and O (f) Li and Li⊕(g) Ba and Sr (h) IE2 of B  and IE2 of C
questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.chapter: Classification of Elements and Periodicity in Properties
questions.explanation:
Five pairs are, in which 2nd species has lower IE than the first species. These are:

(a) Ionisation energy of Be>B because Be with 1s22s2 has fulfilled s-orbital configuration. Hence, loosing an electron becomes difficult. Boron has 1s22s23s1 can loose the outer most electron easily to attain stable configuration. Hence, boron has less ionisation potential than beryllium. 

(b) Ionisation energy of P 3s23p3>S 3s23p4 because P has half-filled configuration of outer most shell.

(c) Ionisation energy of O 2s22p4>S 3s23p4 because O belongs to the second period, while S belongs to the 3rd period. Down the group size increases ionization energy decreases. 

(d) Ionisation energy of Br>K because across the period size decreases due to increase in effective nuclear charge and as a result ionisation energy increases.

(e) Ionisation energy of   N 2s22p3>S3s23p4 because N has half -filled configuration.

3-pairs in which the 1stspecies has lower IE than the 2nd species.

(f) Ionisation energy of  Li1s22s1<Li⊕1s2 because Li⊕  has full-filled configuration.

(g) Ba6s2<Sr 5s2  because down the group ionisation energy decreases due to increase in size of the atom.

(h)  IE2of C < IE2 of B because B has full filled configuration after losing 1 electron.

questions.content:
The minimum volume of water required to dissolve 2.78 g lead II chloride to get a saturated solution(Ksp of PbCl2=3.2×10−8

molar mass of PbCl2=278 g mol-1 ) is______ L.
questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.explanation:
PbCl2⇌Pb2++2Cl-                S       2S

Ksp=Pb2+[Cl]2=(S)(2S)2

=4S3

∴  4S3=3.2×10-8

S=3.2×10-143=2×10-3 mol L-1

Now, Molarity= No.of moles  Volume of solution(L) 

∴Molarity= Mass of substance  Molar mass  ×1 Volume of solution (L) 


∴  2×10-3=2.78278×1 Volume of solution (L) 

 ∴Volume of solution =2.78(278)×2×10-3=5L

∴Minimum volume of water required to dissolve 2.78g PbCl2 to get saturated solution is 5 L.

In the given reaction

If one mole of each X and Y with 0.05 mol of Z gives compound XYZ3.

(Given: Atomic masses of X, Y, and Z are 10, 20 and 30 amu respectively)

The yield of XYZ3 is -------g.

Round off to the nearest integer.
questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.explanation:
X+Y+3Z⇌XYZ3

Given that number of moles X=Y=1 & Z=0.05 mol.

The limiting reagent of the reaction can be calculated using the ratio of moles given to the stoichiometric coefficients ratio.

for X, 11=1for Y, 11=1and for Z,0.053

Hence, the reagent Z is the limiting reagent. The product formed is depends on the limiting reagent.

Limiting reagent is the substance that is totally consumed when the chemical reaction is complete.

Moles to Stoichiometric coefficients ratio is same for product and limiting reagent.

⇒0.053=n1

Hence, the mass of the product =0.053×(10+20+90)=2g

questions.content:
The entropy change involved in the isothermal reversible expansion of 1 mole of an ideal gas from a volume of 20 L to 200 L at 300 K is ____J K-1.

Give the answer after rounding off to the nearest integer value.
questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.explanation:
We know that work done in isothermal reversible expansion, 

qrev=-wmax=2.303×nRT log10V2V1

Given that, 

n=1, R=8.314 J K-1 mol-1, T=300 K

V1=20 L,V2=200 L

Putting the values in the above equation.

∴  qrev=2.303×1×8.314×300×log1020020

=2.303×1×8.314×300×log10(10)

=2.303×1×8.314×300

Now, the change in entropy 

ΔS=qrevT

∴  ΔS=2.303×1×8.314×300300=19.15 J K-1

So the Entropy change is ≅19 JK-1

So, weight of solute=99.94 g≅100g

questions.content: Let <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>R</mi></math> be a relation on <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>Z</mi><mo>×</mo><mi>Z</mi></math> defined by <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mi>b</mi><mo>)</mo><mi>R</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mi>d</mi><mo>)</mo></math> if and only if <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>a</mi><mi>d</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>b</mi><mi>c</mi></math> is divisible by <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>5</mn></math> . Then <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi></math> is
questions.subject: Mathematics

options.content: Reflexive and symmetric but not transitive
Reflexive but neither symmetric not transitive
Reflexive and transitive but not symmetric

questions.explanation:
Given relation R : a,b R c,d

And ad-bc=5k where k∈Z

Now, for reflexive R : a,b R a,b

⇒ab-ba=0 which is divisible by 5

So, the relation is reflexive,

Now, for symmetric R : c,d R a,b

⇒ bc-ad=-5k  which is divisible by 5

So, the relation is symmetric,

Now for transitive relation, R : a,b R c,d R e,f 

Taking example a,b≡1,2, c,d≡10,10, e,f≡4,4

Now, ad-bc=10-20=-10

cf-ed=40-40=0

But af-be=8-4=4 which is not divisible by 5,

Hence, the relation is reflexive, symmetric but not transitive.

Now taking, Case I: x<-2, we get

And y=x2+2 is decreasing ∀x∈(-∞,-2)

Now taking Case II: -2≤x<1 we get,

⇒a=x2-2x-2

And y=x2-2x-2 

So, dydx=2x-1≤0 ∀ x∈[-2,1)

Hence, y is decreasing ∀x∈[-2,1)

Now taking Case III: x≥1 we get,

x2-x+x+2+a=0

⇒a=-x2+2

And y=-x2+2 is decreasing ∀x∈[1,∞)

Hence, from all the cases we can say that nature of function is continuously decreasing so, it will cut x-axis only one time,

∴ Exactly one real root ∀ a∈R

questions.content: The equation of the circle whose radius is <math><mn>5</mn></math> units and which touches the circle <math><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>20</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> externally at the point <math><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mn>5,5</mn></mrow></mfenced></math> is
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.explanation:
The equation of the given circle is

x2+y2-2x-4y-20=0
Its centre is C11,2 and radius =5.

The circle touches another circle of radius 5 externally at P5,5. Let its centre be C2h,k.
Clearly, P5,5 is the midpoint of C1C2.

Therefore,
h+12=5 and k+22=5⇒h=9,k=8.

Hence, the equation of the required circle is
x-h2+y-k2=52

⇒x-92+y-82=52

questions.content:
If the system of equations
2x+y-z=5

2x-5y+λz=μ

x+2y-5z=7
has infinitely many solutions, then(λ+μ)2+(λ-μ)2 is equal to
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.explanation:
Given system of equations.

2x+y-z=5

2x-5y+λz=μ

x+2y-5z=7

For infinite solution Δ=0=Δ1=Δ2=Δ3

⇒Δ=21-12-5λ12-5=0

⇒51-3λ=0

⇒λ=17

⇒Δ3=521μ2-5712=0

⇒-3(μ+13)=0

⇒μ=-13

Now (λ+μ)2+(λ-μ)2

=(17+13)2+(17-13)2

=900+16

=916

Hence this is the correct option.

 α+β=-λ3, αβ=-13⇒α2β2=19

then α2+β2=α+β2-2αβ=λ29-2-13=λ29+23

 ⇒α2+β2=λ2+69

Now 1α2+1β2=15⇒α2+β2α2β2=15

⇒λ2+69×1α2β2=15  ⇒λ2+69×119=15

⇒λ2+6=15 ⇒λ=±3

Now 6α3+β32 =6α+βα2-αβ+β22

questions.content:
Let a function f:R→R be defined as, fx=sinx−ex if x≤0a+-x if 0<x<12x−b if  x≥1

Where x is the greatest integer less than or equal to x. If f is continuous on R, then a+b is equal to:
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.explanation:
We have,

fx=sinx−ex if  x≤0a+-x if  0<x<12x−b if  x≥1

If fx is continuous at x=a then limx→a-fx=fa=limx→a+fx.

Continuous at x=0

f0+=f0-

⇒ a-1=0-e0

⇒ a=0

Continuous at x=1

f1+=f1-

⇒  21-b=a+-1

⇒  b=2-a+1

⇒ b=3

∴  a+b=3

Distance formula =(x2-x1)2+(y2-y1)2

⇒PR=(-3+1)2+(4-0)2& RQ=(0+1)2+22

=50(20+5)=1250

questions.explanation:
Given that limx→0 a+bcosx x-csinxx5=1

Since limit is of 00 form .

Apply L'Hospital rule , we get

limx→0 a+bcosx×1+x-bsinx-ccosx5x4=1

For limit to be exist, we get a+b-c=0

Again, limx→0 -bxcosx+sinx+csinx-bsinx20x3=1

⇒limx→0 -b-xsinx+cosx+cosx+ccosx-bcosx60x2=1

questions.content: Let the eccentricity of an ellipse x2a2+y2b2=1 is reciprocal to that of the hyperbola 2x2-2y2=1. If the ellipse intersects the hyperbola at right angles, then square of length of the latus-rectum of the ellipse is _____.
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.explanation:
Given,

The eccentricity of an ellipse x2a2+y2b2=1 is reciprocal to that of the hyperbola 2x2-2y2=1,

Now eccentricity of rectangular hyperbola 2x2-2y2=1 is eH=2

So, ee=12

Now, focus of hyperbola =±1, 0

Now given that both curve intersect orthogonally, so ellipse and hyperbola are confocal

So, for ellipse aee=1⇒a=2

Now length of latusrectum L.R.=2b2a=2a1-ee2

=22.12=2

questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.explanation:
Given,

a→=31, 4b→=c→=2, 2a→×b→=3c→×a→ and angle between b→ & c→ is given as 2π3

Now solving, 3c→×a→+2b→×a→=0

⇒3c→×2b→×a→=0

Means 3c→×2b→ & a→ are parallel vector,

So, let 3c→×2b→=λa→

Now squaring both sides we get,
9c→2+4b→2+12b→·c→=λ2a→2

⇒36+1+12×12×2cos2π3=λ231

⇒λ2=1

⇒λ=±1

Now putting the value of λ in 3c→×2b→=λa→ we get,

3c→+2b→=±a→      …1

Now taking dot product with b→ in above equation we get,

3b→·c→+2b→·b→=±a→·b→

⇒a→·b→=±-32+12=±-1

⇒a→·b→2=1

Again taking 3c→×a→=2a→×b→ and sqauring both side,

⇒c→×a→2=49a→×b→2

⇒c→×a→2=49a→2b→2-a→·b→2

⇒c→×a→2=49314-1

⇒c→×a→2=49×274=3

Hence, the value of a→×c→a→·b→2=31=3.

questions.content: In an examination, there are <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>10</mn></math> true-false type questions. Out of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>10</mn></math>, a student can guess the answer of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>4</mn></math> questions correctly with probability <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>4</mn></mfrac></math> and the remaining <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>6</mn></math> questions correctly with probability <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>4</mn></mfrac></math>. If the probability that the student guesses the answers of exactly <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>8</mn></math> questions correctly out of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>10</mn></math> is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfrac><mrow><mn>27</mn><mi>k</mi></mrow><msup><mn>4</mn><mn>10</mn></msup></mfrac></math>, then <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>k</mi></math> is equal to

Total probability  =141034×15×32+4×33×6×3+6×32

=2741027×15+72+2

Now comparing with 27k410

We get, k=479

questions.content: Let the set of all <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>a</mi><mo>∈</mo><mi>R</mi></math> such that the equation <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>cos</mi><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>sin</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>a</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>7</mn></math> has a solution be <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>[</mo><mi>p</mi><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mi>q</mi><mo>]</mo></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>tan</mi><mn>9</mn><mo>°</mo><mo>-</mo><mi>tan</mi><mn>27</mn><mo>°</mo><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><mi>cot</mi><mn>63</mn><mo>°</mo></mrow></mfrac><mo>+</mo><mi>tan</mi><mn>81</mn><mo>°</mo></math>, then <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>p</mi><mi>q</mi><mi>r</mi></math> is equal to ________.
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.explanation:
Given: cos2x+a·sinx=2a-7

⇒1-2sin2x+a×sinx=2a-7

⇒a×sinx-2a=-8+2sin2x

⇒asinx-2=2sin2x-4

⇒a(sinx-2)=2(sinx-2)(sinx+2)

⇒sinx=2 Not possible, a=2(sinx+2)

We know that, -1≤sinx≤1

⇒a∈[2,6]

⇒p=2, q=6

Now, r=tan9°+cot9°-tan27°-cot27°

⇒r=cos29°+sin29°sin9°·cos9°-cos227°+sin227°sin27°·cos27°

⇒r=1sin9°·cos9°-1sin27°·cos27°

⇒r=22×sin9°·cos9°-22×sin27°·cos27°

⇒r=2sin18°-2sin54°

⇒r=245-1-45+1

⇒r=85+1-5+15-1

⇒r=824

⇒r=4

⇒p·q·r=2×6×4

⇒p·q·r=48

questions.content: A bag contains <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>4</mn></math> white and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>6</mn></math> black balls. Three balls are drawn at random from the bag. Let <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>X</mi></math> be the number of white balls, among the drawn balls. If <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msup><mi>σ</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math> is the variance of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>X</mi></math>, then <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>100</mn><msup><mi>σ</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math> is equal to
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.explanation:
Given,

X= Number of white ball drawn,

And bag contains 4 white and 6 black balls, total 3 balls are to be drawn,

So, PX=0=C36C310=16

PX=1=C26×C14C310=12

PX=2=C16×C24C310=310

and PX=3=C06×C34C310=130

X 0 1 2 3
PX 16 12 310 130

So, variance =σ2=∑PiXi2-∑PiXi2

⇒σ2=12+1210+310-12+610+1102

⇒σ2=56100

⇒100σ2=56

questions.content: Let <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>a</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>b</mi></math> be two non-zero real numbers. If <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>p</mi></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>r</mi></math> are the roots of the equation <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>8</mn><mi>a</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>q</mi></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>s</mi></math> are the roots of the equation <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>12</mn><mi>b</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, such that <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mi>p</mi></mfrac><mo>,</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mi>q</mi></mfrac><mo>,</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mi>r</mi></mfrac><mo>,</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><mo> </mo><mi>s</mi></mrow></mfrac></math> are in A.P., then <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msup><mi>a</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup><mo>-</mo><msup><mi>b</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></math> is equal to _____ .
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.explanation:
Since p, r are roots of x2-8ax+2a=0 and

q,s are the roots of x2+12bx+6b=0 

So the equation 2ax2-8ax+1=0 has roots 1p,1r and

6bx2+12bx+1=0 has roots 1q,1s.

Given that 1p,1q,1r,1s are in A.P.

Let 1p=α-3β,1q=α-β,1r=α+β and 1s=α+3β

i.e. 1p+1r=2α-2β=4 and

1q+1s=2α+2β=-2

or α=12, β=-32

i.e. 1p=5, 1q=2, 1r=-1, 1s=-4

Now 

1p×1r=12a=-5⇒1a=-10 and 1q×1s=16b=-8⇒1b=-48

Hence, a-1-b-1=-10+48=38
